Issues.Title: Lazy Load Guards
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

router

### Description

Angular supports lazy loaded modules, but if you have a guard for that route, the guard is not lazy loaded but bundled in the parent module. 

The problem is the guard itself can have bloated code/libraries, so why bundle the guard code in the main app if it's not run until the user clicks on a route? 

I am implementing an auth guard, and using aws amplify-js for it, and their method that checks if user is logged in adds 333.82kb to the main bundle - see https://github.com/aws-amplify/amplify-js/issues/9817#issuecomment-1123013402

### Proposed solution

Guards should be lazily loaded. 

### Alternatives considered

Add the canActivate setting in the child route paths and not the parent route path.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Lazy Load Guards" (#45981)

Issues.Title: build: use clone instead of init for creating the builds commit changes
Issues.Body:
Rather than using git init to create an empty repo and then shallow fetch the
repo for a specific branch, we shallow clone the repository itself for the branch.
This prevents us from running into the issue of Github denying the push because it
comes from a shallow branch which does not map back to the repository.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: use clone instead of init for creating the builds commit changes" (#45975)

Issues.Title: Help Visual Studio Code detect secondary entry points
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

common

### Description

Visual Studio Code not autocompletes / autodiscovers secondary entry point modules.



### Proposed solution

In the secondary entry points like common, that holds the `HttpClientModule` is not autodiscovered by visual studio code.

And you have to manually lookup in the docs and import it.

We are mantainers of libraries and we have fixed it importing in the secondary entry point `index.ts` file the submodules index.ts for example:

module1 folder
  index.ts -> exports all his module parts

module 2 folder
  index.ts -> exports all his module parts

main secondary entry point that has module 1 and 2 folders
index.ts -> import module1 and module2 index.ts

This doesnt affect tree shaking and visual studio code autocompletes!

Only cyclic modules give problems.

### Alternatives considered

I think there are no alternatives.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Help Visual Studio Code detect secondary entry points" (#45973)

Issues.Title: Provide an alternative to explicit use of webpack's `file-loader`
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

core

### Description

For locality‚Äôs sake and in order to avoid clutter in `/assets`, I like the idea of having assets near the component‚Äôs code. In addition to this, we can get cache busting using webpack & `file-loader`.

The common webpack-coupled solution is:
```ts
class LogoCmp {
  pictureUri = require('!!file-loader!./logo.avif');
}
```
or more elegantly using import but it requires excluding the file types in tsconfig
```ts
import logoUri from '!!file-loader!./logo.avif';

class LogoCmp {
  pictureUri = logoUri;
}
```

I‚Äôm using the example of a picture here but it could be anything else.
Then there is the webpack resourceQuery technique which requires a custom webpack config and it is still webpack coupled  https://webpack.js.org/configuration/module/#ruleoneof

Is there an abstraction I‚Äôm missing? or can we imagine one?



### Proposed solution

What about a function like `getAssetUrl(relativePath)` or something like that where the compiler would do the job no matter what bundler is underneath?
This could also leverage other functions like `getImages(...)` that provide pictures in different dimensions/formats etc‚Ä¶

### Alternatives considered

Implement some prebuild machinery that builds assets in `/assets` and generates some `ts` file with the generated cache busted URLs... but it feels like the `grunt` times üë¥üèª
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Provide an alternative to explicit use of webpack's `file-loader`" (#45971)

Issues.Title: fix(language-service): Prevent TSServer from removing templates from ‚Ä¶
Issues.Body:
‚Ä¶project

As part of the `updateProjectIfDirty` process and inside `updateNonInferredProjectFiles`
TS Server will remove the template files that we added as roots in
`readResource`.
https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/microsoft/TypeScript@c300fea3250abd7f75920d95a58d9e742ac730ee/-/blob/src/server/editorServices.ts?L2363

The external files are added to the list here so ensuring that the
templates are included in the `getExternalFiles` will prevent this from
happening
https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/microsoft/TypeScript@c300fea3250abd7f75920d95a58d9e742ac730ee/-/blob/src/server/editorServices.ts?L2395:18

Reviewer note: there are no tests here because we don't simulate the whole situation in the language service tests well enough. The currently [failing test](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/angular/vscode-ng-language-service/3530/workflows/8ff8accd-6814-44c9-b810-db504d175a91/jobs/3458) in the vscode extension repo does pass with this change. Unfortunately, it's not included in this mono-repo, which is why it's hard to show and how this issue was introduced in the first place.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(language-service): Prevent TSServer from removing templates from ‚Ä¶" (#45965)

Issues.Title: Define Angular Custom element without ngModules
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

elements

### Description

Hello team,
So without standalone on to define a custom element as you know we use below syntax:
```
export class AppModule implements DoBootstrap {
  constructor(private injector: Injector) {}

  public ngDoBootstrap(): void {
    const ce = createCustomElement(AppComponent, { injector: this.injector });
    customElements.define('likes-app-element', ce);
  }
}
```
But how should we do this without `NgModules`?
I tried to add above snippet to `AppComponent` but seems it does not create custom element and we receive error:
`the selector "likes-app-root" did not match any elements.`
I think this is because we already bootstrap AppComponent in main.ts file. With ngModules we could prevent bootstrapping by specifying bootstrap: [].  To prevent bootstrapping we could just create custom element in bootstrap.ts but we have to provide Injector there.
Thanks.

### Proposed solution

I think we should be able to define elements in AppComponent.

### Alternatives considered

Alternative was trying to define element in AppComponent but not working as expected.

### Version
Angular 14.0.0-rc.0
Plaground branch: https://github.com/vugar005/youtube-webapp-turborepo/tree/feature/preview-angular-v14.0.0-rc.0/apps/likes-app
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Define Angular Custom element without ngModules" (#45969)

Issues.Title: strictly-typed form controls can lie about their type nullability
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

forms

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

See the stackblitz below.

TL;DR even though we use a `FormControl<number>`, its value can be null, simply because the CVA of inputs of type number sets the value to null.

The strictly-typed forms are not very consistent, IMHO, regarding the type insurance they provide. For example:

- they force us to have nullable values just in case one calls `reset()`, which unfortunately sets the value to null, unless we explicitly use the option `initialValueIsDefault`. Even though, in my experience, calling `reset()` is extremely rare.
- they force us to have undefined-able values in form groups just in case one would disable a control, thus making its value absent of the form group's value. Disabling fields is more common in my experience than calling `reset()`, but still quite rare.

But on the other hand:
- they don't care at all if the CVA used to set the control's value sets it to null (like in the example in the stackblitz). Using number inputs, or select boxes with a default null option, for example, is extremely common in my experience. And in that case, the non-nullability of the FormControl is a lie.

I would expect more consistency:
- either forms are paranoid, and don't ever let the typing lie, but in that case, a form control initialized with the `initialValueIsDefault` option and a non null initial value should check that its value is never set to null and throw if it's the case (like in the provided example)
- or forms should give the control of the type to the developer: if they know that they never call reset(), and that they never disable a control, and that the CVA never sets the value to null, then let them choose the type they want, and too bad for them if they screwed up (i.e. basically what happens every type you do `http.get<Something>()`)


### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-tjtyng-kz6zuz?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.module.ts,src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.html,src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.ts,package.json,src%2Fstyles.scss,angular.json,src%2Findex.html

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
NA
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular 14.0.0-rc.0
```


### Anything else?

_No response_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "strictly-typed form controls can lie about their type nullability" (#45968)

Issues.Title: feat(common): support custom srcset attributes in NgOptimizedImage
Issues.Body: (Ignore first commit, need to rebase once #45961 goes in) This commit adds a `rawSrcset` attribute as a replacement for the `srcset` attribute. The `srcset` attribute cannot be set statically on the image directive because it would cause images to start downloading before the "loading" attribute could be set to "lazy". Changing the name to `rawSrcset` allows the directive to control the timing of image loading. It also makes it possible to support custom loaders for `srcset` file names. Rather than having to repeat the image origin for each image, the existing `rawSrc` value and image loader can be composed to generate each full URL string. The developer must only provide the necessary widths for the `srcset`. For example, the developer might write: ```markup ``` with a loader like: ```js const loader = (config) => `path/${config.src}?w=${config.width}`; ``` and the img tag will ultimately be set up as something like: ```markup ``` ## PR Checklist Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements: - [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit - [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features) - [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features) ## PR Type What kind of change does this PR introduce? - [x] Bugfix - [x] Feature - [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables) - [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes) - [ ] Build related changes - [ ] CI related changes - [ ] Documentation content changes - [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes - [ ] Other... Issues.Title: i18n $localize function with custom IDs when using variables inside template literals
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

localize

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

When calling the $localize function as follows:

When I run the `ng extract-i18` command against a bunch of $localize calls that look similar to this:

       return $localize`Must be at least ${setting.SettingValue}:minLen: characters long.`;

Angular will generate the following xlf output:

    `<trans-unit id="2927300519471273952" datatype="html">
        <source>Must contain at least <x id="nonAlphaNum" equiv-text="setting.SettingValue"/> symbols.</source>
        <context-group purpose="location">
          <context context-type="sourcefile">src/app/core/modals/password-edit-modal/password-edit.modal.ts</context>
          <context context-type="linenumber">105</context>
        </context-group>
      </trans-unit>`

However, if I try and use a CUSTOM ID instead - it doesn't work.
   For example, only changing the `id` attrib: `<trans-unit **id="passwordNonAlphNum"** datatype="html">`

I am using a website service to store all the source translations, so having a custom ID makes it easier to search up and distinguish btwn other related messages.






### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

_No response_

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
If I use a custom ID in place of the random ID which Angular generates, then it will NOT pull the translation from the `<target>` element of my xlf.
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 13.0.3
Node: 12.21.0
Package Manager: npm 6.14.11
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 13.0.2
... animations, cdk, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, localize, material
... material-moment-adapter, platform-browser
... platform-browser-dynamic, router, service-worker

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1300.3
@angular-devkit/build-angular   13.0.3
@angular-devkit/core            13.0.3
@angular-devkit/schematics      13.0.3
@angular/cli                    13.0.3
@angular/flex-layout            13.0.0-beta.36
@schematics/angular             13.0.3
rxjs                            6.6.7
typescript                      4.4.4
```


### Anything else?

_No response_

Issues.Title: service-worker: configure response status codes to treat as failed/offline with freshness strategy
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

service-worker

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description


Expected behaviour: freshness strategy should return to user fetching requested data only if request was successful.
If request is unsuccessful (has 500, 504 and other codes) it should return cached result instead of bad result. And bad result should not be cached at all.

But in reality:

freshness strategy return for user bad results.

Interestingly, freshness strategy works as expected if web-server absolutely died (network error: connection refused). I mean, all configured in dataGroup requests begin to return from cache and web-application works despite dead backend. It is different with particular bad request (as I described above).

Performance strategy works as expected (it returns cached results firstly)

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

_No response_

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

_No response_

### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 11.2.19
Node: 14.8.2
OS: darwin x64

Angular: 11.2.14
```


### Anything else?

https://angular.io/guide/service-worker-config#datagroups

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/69132411/angular-service-worker-return-cached-response-if-server-returns-error
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "service-worker: configure response status codes to treat as failed/offline with freshness strategy" (#45954)

Issues.Title: feat(forms): Add explicit selectors for all built-in ControlValueAccessors
Issues.Body:
## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [X] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [ ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [ ] Bugfix
- [X] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?

From the number of built-in ControlValueAccessors, only the `DefaultValueAccessor` can be applied to a component indivudially (using the `ngDefaultControl` attribute selector).
All others can only be created by attaching a FormControl or ngModel.

Issue Number: N/A


## What is the new behavior?

All built-in ControlValueAccessors can be created individually using an attribute selector that follows the same naming pattern as `ngDefaultControl`.

This change allows for UI libraries to encapsulate not only text-inputs but also other kinds of inputs without the need to fully implement the ControlValueAccessor. Instead they can act as a proxy to the built-in ControlValueAccessor.

I have built an example that currently works with text-inputs, this PR will make it work with other input-types as well. https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-xblubc?file=src/app/custom-input/custom-input.component.ts

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [X] No


<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->


## Other information

Issues.Title: feat(@schematics/angular): support controlling `addDependency` utility rule install behavior
Issues.Body:
When using the `addDependency` rule from `@schematics/angular/utility` a new option is now
available that supports controlling the rule's behavior when scheduling the `NodePackageInstallTask`.
Previously, the behavior was automatic and the rule would only schedule the task if it was not already
scheduled by a previous `addDependency` rule usage for the `package.json`. This behavior is still the
default behavior. However, it can now be customized per rule invocation via the `install` rule option
which can be either `InstallBehavior.None`, `InstallBehavior.Auto`, or `InstallBehavior.Always`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@schematics/angular): support controlling `addDependency` utility rule install behavior" (#23128)

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/schematics): allow `chain` rule to accept iterables of rules
Issues.Body:
Previously, the `chain` base rule only accepted an `Array` of schematics rules.
In addition to still allowing an `Array`, `chain` now can accept either an `Iterable<Rule>`
or `AsyncIterable<Rule>`. This provides support for sync and async generator functions
with the `chain` rule.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@angular-devkit/schematics): allow `chain` rule to accept iterables of rules" (#23127)

evanw/esbuild ### [`v0.14.39`](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#​01439) [Compare Source](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/compare/v0.14.38...v0.14.39) - Fix code generation for `export default` and `/* @​__PURE__ */` call ([#​2203](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/2203)) The `/* @​__PURE__ */` comment annotation can be added to function calls to indicate that they are side-effect free. These annotations are passed through into the output by esbuild since many JavaScript tools understand them. However, there was an edge case where printing this comment before a function call caused esbuild to fail to parenthesize a function literal because it thought it was no longer at the start of the expression. This problem has been fixed: ```js // Original code export default /* @​__PURE__ */ (function() { })() // Old output export default /* @​__PURE__ */ function() { }(); // New output export default /* @​__PURE__ */ (function() { })(); ``` - Preserve `...` before JSX child expressions ([#​2245](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/2245)) TypeScript 4.5 changed how JSX child expressions that start with `...` are emitted. Previously the `...` was omitted but starting with TypeScript 4.5, the `...` is now preserved instead. This release updates esbuild to match TypeScript's new output in this case: ```jsx // Original code console.log({...b}) // Old output console.log(/* @​__PURE__ */ React.createElement("a", null, b)); // New output console.log(/* @​__PURE__ */ React.createElement("a", null, ...b)); ``` Note that this behavior is TypeScript-specific. Babel doesn't support the `...` token at all (it gives the error "Spread children are not supported in React"). - Slightly adjust esbuild's handling of the `browser` field in `package.json` ([#​2239](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/2239)) This release changes esbuild's interpretation of `browser` path remapping to fix a regression that was introduced in esbuild version 0.14.21. Browserify has a bug where it incorrectly matches package paths to relative paths in the `browser` field, and esbuild replicates this bug for compatibility with Browserify. I have a set of tests that I use to verify that esbuild's replication of this Browserify is accurate here: https://github.com/evanw/package-json-browser-tests. However, I was missing a test case and esbuild's behavior diverges from Browserify in this case. This release now handles this edge case as well: - `entry.js`: ```js require('pkg/sub') ``` - `node_modules/pkg/package.json`: ```json { "browser": { "./sub": "./sub/foo.js", "./sub/sub.js": "./sub/foo.js" } } ``` - `node_modules/pkg/sub/foo.js`: ```js require('sub') ``` - `node_modules/sub/index.js`: ```js console.log('works') ``` The import path `sub` in `require('sub')` was previously matching the remapping `"./sub/sub.js": "./sub/foo.js"` but with this release it should now no longer match that remapping. Now `require('sub')` will only match the remapping `"./sub/sub": "./sub/foo.js"` (without the trailing `.js`). Browserify apparently only matches without the `.js` suffix here.

Issues.Title: Different handling of EcmaScript version specific features in JS and TS code
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? I don't know. ### Description I have a problem with Logical OR assignments: When I use a Logical OR assignment in a TypeScript file and compile it with Angular Cli it is converted from `a ||= b` to `a || (a = b)` up to ES2020. With ES2021 it stays unchanged. If such a Logical OR assignment is used in a JS lib (in my case pdfjs-dist) it is converted until ES5, but from ES6/ES2015 on it stays unchanged. ES5 ![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5774027/168065433-4253dcbf-ccac-48ee-9938-aef15043a98b.png) ES2015 ![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5774027/168064946-9525d35f-b88c-4d38-82be-17667b96c43d.png) The browserlist setting seem's to have no impact. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Create a plain Angular project, install a lib that contains a logical or assignment like pdfjs-dist, play around with the target property in tsconfig.json. ## üî• Exception or Error Generated TS and JS code differs in usage of EcmaScript features. We detected it, because we have used an older Chrome version (83) for testing, which suddenly failed, because the `||=` was unkown. ## üåç Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 13.3.5
Node: 16.14.2
Package Manager: npm 8.6.0
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 13.3.7
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1303.5
@angular-devkit/build-angular   13.3.5
@angular-devkit/core            13.3.5
@angular-devkit/schematics      13.3.5
@angular/cli                    13.3.5
@schematics/angular             13.3.5
rxjs                            7.5.5
typescript                      4.6.4
**Anything else relevant?**

Issues.Body:
Best viewed [ignoring whitespace](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/23114/files?w=1).

When working on the bazel e2e tests (#23074) we might run tests in parallel such as bazel + non-bazel, npm + yarn etc.

Unfortunately the verdaccio `--listen` only sets the primary port and not the fallback which we need to also set, so we need to do the `.replace` thing :(

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): properly handle locally-built APF v14 libraries
Issues.Body:
Locally-built APF v14 libraries should be resolved properly. Webpack
currently does not resolve them (in e.g. `dist/`) because the local
distribution folders are not marked as module roots, causing Webpack
to never hit the `resolve-in-package` with the proper description file (of
the locally built-package) and therefore skipping package exports resolution
and breaking secondary entry-points from being resolved properly (when bundling).

We fix this by determining local module/package roots through the
tsconfig. Ideally we could have leveraged information from other targets
in the project but the builder does not have access to that, and
leveraging tsconfig `paths` might also make this more flexible.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): properly handle locally-built APF v14 libraries" (#23106)

Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: update angular" (#23116)

Issues.Title: test: remove use of global npm installs
Issues.Body:
Removing the use of globally installed npm and npm packages. Instead npm+yarn within the test-runner use npm+yarn from package.json (not globals). Tests no longer depend on any `--global` and use npm+ng installed locally within the temporary test directories.

This might be the last step before being able to run multiple tests concurrently (https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/23114 was the other big one).

This might be the last one before getting the e2e tests working in bazel (https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/23074)

#### What's Changed

##### Feats

-   feat: add `husky -` prefix to logged global error messages by [@​joshbalfour](https://togithub.com/joshbalfour) in [https://github.com/typicode/husky/pull/1092](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/pull/1092)

-   feat: drop Node 12 support
-   feat: skip install if `$HUSKY=0`

##### Fixes

-   fix: hook script use `/usr/bin/env sh` instead of direct path of `sh` by [@​skhaz](https://togithub.com/skhaz) in [https://github.com/typicode/husky/pull/1051](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/pull/1051)

-   fix: force `basename`/`dirname` to treat `$0` as an argument by [@​mataha](https://togithub.com/mataha) in [https://github.com/typicode/husky/pull/1132](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/pull/1132)

-   docs: add dog emoji as favicon by [@​jamiehaywood](https://togithub.com/jamiehaywood) in [https://github.com/typicode/husky/pull/1095](https://togithub.com/typicode/husky/pull/1095)

Issues.Title: Add support for Node.JS v18 (lack of it possibly causes unbound breakpoints)
Issues.Body:
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] extract-i18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [x] version
- [ ] doc

Once I updated my system from Node.JS 16.15.0 to 18.1.0, breakpoints in Angular code stopped working - they became unbound.
After I've downgraded Node.JS back to v16 they started working again.

When running "ng --version", I got:
Angular CLI: 13.3.5
Node: 18.1.0 (Unsupported)
Package Manager: npm 8.9.0
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 13.3.6
... animations, cdk, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, localize, material, platform-browser
... platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1303.5
@angular-devkit/build-angular   13.3.5
@angular-devkit/core            13.3.5
@angular-devkit/schematics      13.3.5
@angular/cli                    13.3.5
@schematics/angular             13.3.5
rxjs                            7.5.5
typescript                      4.4.4

Warning: The current version of Node (18.1.0) is not supported by Angular.


I'm assuming the unbound breakpoints problem is because Node.JS 18 is not yet supported.
Can you please add support for it?

Issues.Title: SCSS file paths with custom base-href are wrong
Issues.Body: # üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [x] build ### Is this a regression? No, didn't work in previous versions as mentioned but not properly solved here #4782 or here #18043 ## üî¨ Description & Minimal Reproduction 1) `ng new test-app` 2) Place a picture in `src/assets` **_We have to look at 2 different build environments:_** #### 1) Default dev env with `ng serve` The default base-href is ``, which means all URIs don't have a prefix and have the default root. | Syntax | Status | | ----------- | ----------- | |`` | works, but ignores the base-href | |`` | works, is relative path from the root | |`background-imge: url('/assets/img.png')` | works, but ignores the base-href | |`background-imge: url('assets/img.png')` | works not | |`background-imge: url('~src/assets/img.png')` | works, why?? | #### 2) Serving a production build using a webserver like nginx or apache Now we set the base-href to `` in index.html and set in **angular.json** `"baseHref": "/app/",` in `architect/configurations/production` and run `ng build`. | Syntax | Status | | ----------- | ----------- | | `` | works not, because we have /app/ prefix after root | | `` | works, path is updated to /app/assets/img.png by compiler | | `` | same as above | | `background-imge: url('/assets/img.png')` | works not, because we have /app/ prefix after root | | `background-imge: url('assets/img.png')` | works not, build fails | | `background-imge: url('./assets/img.png')` | works not, build fails | | `background-imge: url('~src/assets/img.png')` | ~~works not~~ **update: works** | | `background-imge: url('~assets/img.png')` | works not, build fails | | `background-imge: url('/app/assets/img.png')` | works, but uses root routing and breaks dev env | **TLDR:** There is no way to access asset files in SCSS with a changed base-href, without hardcoding the base-href in SCSS like `/app/assets/img.png` but breaking the local dev env. ## üî• Exception or Error ```sh ./src/app/elements/phone-frame/phone-frame.component.scss?ngResource - Error: Module Error (from ./node_modules/postcss-loader/dist/cjs.js): /Users/me/repositories/app-frontend/src/app/elements/phone-frame/phone-frame.component.scss:16:28: Can't resolve './assets/images/phone-frame-dark.png' in '/Users/me/repositories/app-frontend/src/app/elements/phone-frame' ``` ## üåç Your Environment ```sh Angular CLI: 13.3.3 Node: 16.13.1 Package Manager: npm 8.1.2 OS: darwin x64 Angular: 13.3.4 ... animations, cdk, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms ... google-maps, material, platform-browser ... platform-browser-dynamic, router, service-worker Package Version --------------------------------------------------------- @angular-devkit/architect 0.1303.3 @angular-devkit/build-angular 13.3.3 @angular-devkit/core 13.3.3 @angular-devkit/schematics 13.3.3 @angular/cli 13.3.3 @schematics/angular 13.3.3 rxjs 6.6.7 typescript 4.4.4 ``` ## Preferred solution The CSS compiler should update the asset paths in CSS/SCSS/SASS files as like the `src` paths in HTML are updated.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "SCSS file paths with custom base-href are wrong" (#23104)

I think this update tool has worked for me in the past but most of the time I just "rebase" my code onto a new project. I'm used to spring boot where to get everything updated I have to copy/paste one or two versions belonging to "bom" bill of material dependencies that set the version for everything else transitively. When I run `ng update` or `npm audit fix --force` what is it trying to do? Every time I read an error from one of these things I feel like I need a visual aid to figure out which version is too far up or down from where the other versions want them to be. `ng update` proposed that everything be set to 13.3.6/13.3.5. That sounded good. How is 14.0.0-next.16 entering the picture? I certainly didn't add it. Is there a full proof guide for everything I need to do to update things and make the vulnerabilities go away?

Issues.Title: bug(mat-selection-list): Focus "ghosts" on iOS
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

On iOS, tapping on an item in a multi-select `mat-selection-list` results in focus styling being briefly applied to the previously focused item:
![mat-selection-list_ios](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6350017/168153515-b2c2dcc3-555e-4337-a6f6-206a22a56651.gif)



### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Select or unselect an item in a multi-select `mat-selection-list` (e.g.: https://material.angular.io/components/list/examples#list-selection) by touching the item on an iOS device.
2. Select or unselect another item in the list.

### Expected Behavior

The focus shading for the first item should not appear when the second item is touched.

### Actual Behavior

The focus shading for the first item appears briefly when the second item is touched.

### Environment

- Angular: (whatever is running on https://material.angular.io/ today)
- CDK/Material: 13.3.7
- Browser(s): Safari, Chrome, Edge
- Operating System: iOS (at least 15.4.x, but probably others)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mat-selection-list): Focus "ghosts" on iOS" (#24916)

Issues.Title: MatDialog: When using in dynamically loaded component workaround deprecated
Issues.Body:
### What are you trying to do?

Main issue that has the bug explanation and 2 workarounds provided: [MatDialog: When using in dynamically loaded component throws error No provider for MatDialog](https://github.com/angular/components/issues/19335#)

>1. Add the `MatDialogModule` to the root module so that the service is available in your whole application
>2. Retrieve the `ComponentFactoryResolver` for the lazy module and instantiate the component through that.

### What troubleshooting steps have you tried?

Out of the two workarounds the first one is going against minifying the initial bundle size and the lazy loading principles in case the material component is used only in the lazy module.
The second @devversion's workaround functions well, however, now that both `ComponentFactoryResolver` and `Compiler` usage is deprecated with Ivy it is something that needs either another workaround or a proper fix. 
Possibly related issue(https://github.com/angular/components/issues/10820) which I have encountered as well, the dynamically loaded components with angular material dependency resolution is in underwhelming state which limits their usage for complex angular applications.

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-m7dysp?file=src/main.ts
2. Notice all the deprecations
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15938416/168039378-e27a36de-f07b-4529-83bc-811390107e2d.png)



### Environment

- Angular: 13.3.0
- CDK/Material: 13.3.0

In the mdc checkbox component, removes the click handler on <label/>
and handles stoping propgation of clicks on the label in the label's
parent. This removes the extra a11y tree node on the label and fixes
TalkBack having an extra navigation stop (https://github.com/angular/components/issues/14385).

A11y tree before this commit. It has an un-necessary node, which
corresponds to the `<label>` element.
```
- Generic
 - Checkbox, "Field A"
 - Textlabel, "Field A"
```

A11y tree with this commit applied
```
- Generic
 - Checkbox, "Field A"
```

fixes https://github.com/angular/components/issues/14385

Issues.Title: fix(material/core): noop animations not applying to selector lists
Issues.Body:
The way the `private-animation-noop` mixin was written meant that if it was included in a list of selectors, it would only be applied to the first selector in the list. This caused some animations in the MDC button not to be disabled.

These changes simplify the mixin, because the old approach was only relevant for on case in the progress spinner that we can write out manually instead.

Issues.Title: bug(mat-chip-list): selectable="false" doesn't work on initial assignment
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Setting `selectable="false"` on MatChipList doesn't work as expected.

The `selectable` property of MatChipList is propagated to the contained chips in line [334](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/567be4f7a71026cce740ce5fde3dc06ae7984f45/src/material/chips/chip-list.ts#L334).

However, the initial input value is set **before** the MatChip ContentChildren are initialized. Thus only later value changes propagate to the individual chips.

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open [StackBlitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-jhyc5a?file=src/app/example-component.html)
   - Initial state of `selectable` is `false`
2. Focus one of the chips
3. Press [SPACE]
   - Selection of focused chip changes (although it shouldn't)
5. Check the "Selectable" checkbox
6. Uncheck the "Selectable" checkbox
7. Focus one of the chips
8. Press [SPACE]
   - Selection of focused chip doesn't change (as expected)


### Expected Behavior

Setting `<mat-chip-list selectable="false">` should prevent selection of chips

### Actual Behavior

Setting `<mat-chip-list selectable="false">` doesn't prevent selection of chips

### Environment

- Angular: 12, 13
- CDK/Material: 12, 13

So example when i enter 01/03/202, it automatically parses the date to 01/02/0202. I do not want this behavior, I want it to keep 01/03/202. I believe the issue is in the [MatDatepickerInputBase](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/material/datepicker/datepicker-input-base.ts) class, the _onInput method calls the parse and format methods of the respective DateAdapter which converts the number to a date object.

Issues.Title: docs-bug(matDialog): afterOpened returns observable<void>
Issues.Body:
### Documentation Feedback

Hello,
The documentation wrongly states that the afterOpened returns a `Subject<MatDialogRef<any>>` but in reality returns `Observable<void>`
https://material.angular.io/components/dialog/api#MatDialog
```ts
/**
 * Reference to a dialog opened via the MatDialog service.
 */
export declare class MatDialogRef<T, R = any> {
    ....
    /**
     * Close the dialog.
     * @param dialogResult Optional result to return to the dialog opener.
     */
    close(dialogResult?: R): void;
    /**
     * Gets an observable that is notified when the dialog is finished opening.
     */
    afterOpened(): Observable<void>;
```

### Affected documentation page

https://material.angular.io/components/dialog/api#MatDialog
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "docs-bug(matDialog): afterOpened returns observable<void>" (#24900)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-select): The selection is repeated twice (+) in screen readers
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

(I have honestly no idea)

### Description

The selection of a basic mat-select gets read multiple time by screen readers, for example this is how it is presented by the chrome accessibility tree (note the two "Pizza"s there):

![Screenshot at 2022-05-09 21-52-28](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/61631103/167498408-90f07771-db07-44f1-b72a-866940d316a6.png)

In voiceOver the value is actually read once as the select value and twice as the label, so it actually gets read three times as you can see here:

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/61631103/167498553-c13866bb-ae13-4fa4-96dc-2b52e23c99b9.mp4


I believe that the issue is caused by assigning to the `labelledby` both the label and the first selected value, as you can see here:
![Screenshot at 2022-05-09 21-55-13](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/61631103/167498641-7d2070c0-2fff-4697-81d1-c26afb4b1816.png)

(note from the video that this does not happen when using native selects)

### Reproduction

Any basic mat-select seems to present this, for example the ones presented in the material docs: https://material.angular.io/components/select/overview

### Expected Behavior

I would expect it to work precisely as the native select elements as that should in theory be the cleanest behavior, if not at the least I would expect the selections not to be read multiple times

### Actual Behavior

the selection gets read multiple times, 2 or 3 times depending on the screen reader

### Environment

- Angular: 13.3.6
- CDK/Material: 13.3.6
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Ubuntu and macOS

### Extra
 - I tried looking for an issue describing the same bug, but I could not find any, sorry if there is one and I missed it
 - I am pretty sure this is not how it should work, sorry if I'm wrong
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mat-select): The selection is repeated twice (+) in screen readers " (#24899)

Issues.Title: fix(google-maps): error when minified through closure
Issues.Body: In #24865 the access of the global `MarkerClusterer` class changed to go through the `window`. This causes a runtime error for apps minified through Closure, because the name is no longer minified and it doesn't align with the minified class name on the `window`. These changes move around our code so that we reference the clusterer without going through the `window`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(google-maps): error when minified through closure" (#24897)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-text-column): Column-name based CSS ignored unless view encapsulation is disabled
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

May not technically be a bug, and more of an undocumented quirk.

There are two aspects to mat-table column definitions that lead to an unexpected conclusion:

- For a column named `foo`, you can define a `.mat-column-foo` style which will get applied to it.
- A `mat-text-column` named `foo` is shorthand for an explicit matColumnDef with sensible defaults for a text-only field.

However, if you define said style, and try to apply it to a mat-text-column, it won't match.

I supppose that technically, the affected th/td elements are no longer generated by the parent view, but by mat-text-node itself - and thus, those are outside the scope of view-encapsulated styles defined there.

The fix may not be trivial, but it might still be worth documenting as a gotcha.

### Reproduction

See StackBlitz [here](https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-e4h1lq?file=src/app/example-component.ts). By making the component non-encapsulated, the style applies to both columns. Otherwise, it only matches the explicitly defined one, not the text-column.

### Expected Behavior

Styles affect matColumnDefs and mat-text-columns the same way.

### Actual Behavior

...they don't!

### Environment

Angular CLI: 13.3.5
Node: 14.17.6
Package Manager: yarn 1.22.15
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 13.3.6
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mat-text-column): Column-name based CSS ignored unless view encapsulation is disabled" (#24893)

Issues.Title: Angular Material Typography: No ability to customize H5 and H6 levels in typography definition
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

Quote from https://material.angular.io/guide/typography: 
_The .mat-h5 and .mat-h6 styles don't directly correspond to a specific Material Design typography level. The .mat-h5 style uses the body-1 level with the font-size scaled down by 0.83. The .mat-h6 style uses the body-1 level with the font-size scaled down by 0.67._
![Screen Shot 2022-05-06 at 11 36 41 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22205168/167165666-675b26f9-b40f-4f18-8c23-b59be74baefe.png)


### Use Case

We have a specific typography guide to implement but have no defined styles for h5 or h6, do to it not corresponding directly to a typography level. 

Are there ways to do this?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Angular Material Typography: No ability to customize H5 and H6 levels in typography definition" (#24892)

Issues.Title: bug(matTooltip): cursor focus continues to be tracked outside the active area
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

12.2.13

### Description

The focus of the cursor continues to be tracked outside the active area and the tooltip remains visible

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Hover over the active area that will display the tooltip message
2. Move the cursor to the side where the message will be displayed (based on [matTooltipPosition] property) **between the active area and the tooltip**


### Expected Behavior

The tooltip should disappear immediately when the focus is outside the active area

### Actual Behavior

The tooltip continues to be displayed even when the cursor is outside the active area

Video record example:
https://www.loom.com/share/5e50731570e8427ebbc104a03cef7b12

### Environment
